newsitem.title: GERMANY: Aon group to take over German group - sources.
newsitem.headline: Aon group to take over German group - sources.

text.p: U.S. Aon Group, the world's second largest insurance broker, is set to acquire German industrial insurance broker Wesselhoeft, Ahlers und Schues KG, insurance sources said on Monday.

These sources told Reuters that a preliminary agreement has been signed between Aon and the Hamburg-based German group. Wesselhoeft, Ahlers and Schues will be sold by the two managing partners Peter Wesselhoeft und Bjoern Ahlers.
Wesselhoeft, Ahlers und Schues KG declined to comment.
The Aon Group recorded revenue of 3.466 billion marks last year, making it one of the leading global players.

In recent months the group has spent large sums expanding its international presence. Its latest acquisition was that of the largest insurance broker in Colombia, Saiz y Cia Ltda Corredores de Seguros.
Meanwhile Wesselhoeft is one of the 10 largest brokers in Germany with a staff of 220 and offices in eight cities.
Revenue from brokerage commission and other services is estimated at between 80 and 90 million marks.

According to the sources, Aon plans to merge Wesselhoeft with its existing German subsidiary Havag/Hudig-Langeveldt Internationaler Versicherungsmakler GmbH, possibly under the name Aon Deutschland or Aon Versicherungsmakler (insurance broker).
Havag is considerably larger than Wesselhoeft with a staff of 300.
Joined into one company, Aon's German operation would be one of the country's top five insurance brokers.

Both concentrate on industrial insurance. In addition, Havag/Hudig-Langeveldt has a reputation as a specialist in the field of fine art insurance, carried out via its subsidiary Artscope Internationaler Kunstversicherungsmakler GmbH. Wesselhoeft owns, with its subsidiary Wacus Kredit-Versicherungsmakler GmbH, Germany's leading specialised broker for credit insurance.
